questions.question: How do you customize Bootstrap's default theme using Sass?

answer_variants.answer: You create your own `.scss` file, change variables like `$primary`, and then import Bootstrap's source files into your project.
To customize Bootstrap, you define your own variable overrides *before* importing Bootstrap's Sass files. This allows you to change the entire color scheme, border radius, or spacing system globally.
The workflow involves importing `functions`, then personal overrides, then `variables`. Use `$theme-colors: map-merge($theme-colors, ('custom': #555));` to add new theme colors.
Customization via SCSS variable overrides before final compilation.
It's like 'Modding a Car'. Instead of sticking to the factory paint job and wheels, you go into the engine (Sass) and change the settings before the car is built.
Define custom Sass variables before importing Bootstrap's source SCSS.

Bootstrap uses the `!default` flag on its internal variables. This means if you define a variable with the same name earlier in your code, Bootstrap will respect your value and ignore its own default.
If you don't like Bootstrap's blue, you can tell it to use 'Pink' everywhere by changing one word in a hidden settings file.
You can also customize the 'options' map, enabling things like `$enable-shadows` or `$enable-gradients` which are turned off by default to keep the CSS light.
The process of altering the framework's visual and functional defaults using Sass variable re-assignment.
Nesting means putting a new `.row` inside an existing `.col` to create a more complex grid inside a column.

To nest your content with the default grid, add a new `.row` and set of `.col-*` columns within an existing `.col-*` column. The nested row will have its own 12-column system based on its parent's width.

Nesting structure: `
...
`. The nested columns' widths are relative to the parent column, not the viewport.
Adding a .row within a .col to create sub-grid structures.
It's like a 'Russian Nesting Doll'. You have a big doll (main grid), and inside it, you find another set of dolls (nested grid) that work exactly the same way but are smaller.
Place a .row inside a .col to initiate a sub-12-column grid.
Nested rows include negative margins to offset the padding of the parent column. This ensures that the first nested column aligns perfectly with the edge of the parent column's content area.
If you have a big column that takes up half the screen, you can split *that half* into smaller pieces by nesting another row inside it.
Deep nesting can become hard to manage. It's often better to use CSS Grid for complex internal layouts and reserve Bootstrap's flex-based grid for the main page structure.
The practice of embedding rows and columns within existing grid cells to create hierarchical layouts.

questions.question: How do 'Offset' classes work in the grid system?

answer_variants.answer: Offset classes add 'empty space' to the left of a column to shift it toward the right.
You use `.offset-*` classes to move columns to the right. These classes increase the left margin of a column by a specific number of grid units (e.g., `.offset-md-4` shifts it by 4 units).
Translates to `margin-left` percentages in the CSS. For example, `.offset-4` adds a `margin-left: 33.3333%` to the column.
Classes for creating horizontal gaps between columns by applying left margins.
It's like 'Indenting a Paragraph' in a word document. You're pushing the text away from the left edge by exactly the amount you specified.
Apply .offset-* to move columns to the right by grid unit increments.

Offsets can be reset at different breakpoints. For example, `.col-md-4 .offset-md-4` will be offset on desktop, but on mobile (where the column becomes full width), you might want to remove the offset using `.offset-0`.
Use 'offset' if you want a column to start in the middle of the screen instead of sticking to the left side.
In many cases, it's more flexible to use flexbox centering utilities like `.justify-content-center` on the row rather than hardcoding offsets on the items.
A set of grid utility classes that add horizontal padding-based or margin-based shifts to column placement.

questions.question: What is 'Column Ordering' and how do you use it?

answer_variants.answer: Ordering allows you to change the visual sequence of columns without changing the order in your HTML code.
By using `.order-*` classes, you can rearrange columns across different devices. For example, you can have a sidebar appear second on desktop but first on mobile for better UX.
Uses the CSS `order` flexbox property. Values range from 1 to 5, plus `.order-first` (-1) and `.order-last` (6).
Flexbox-based utility for resequencing grid columns across breakpoints.
It's like 'Dealing Cards'. Even if you have the Ace in your hand first, you can choose to play it last on the table without changing the fact that you still hold it.
Use .order-1 to .order-5 classes to change column visual sequence.

This is a key feature for SEO. You can put your most important 'Main Content' first in your HTML (so Google sees it immediately), but use `.order-2` on mobile to show the 'Hero Image' at the top of the screen visually.
It's 'cutting in line' for columns. You can tell one box to move to the front or back of the row whenever you want.
Be careful with accessibility: changing the visual order doesn't change the 'Tab order' for keyboard users or screen readers, which can be confusing if the sequence is radically different.
The reordering of visual elements within a flex container using predefined CSS order utility classes.

questions.question: How do you use 'Auto Margins' in a flexbox layout?

answer_variants.answer: Use classes like `ms-auto` (margin-start) or `me-auto` (margin-end) to push elements away from each other automatically.
Auto margins can be used in flex containers to push siblings away. For instance, putting `.ms-auto` on a navbar link will push it (and everything after it) all the way to the right side of the bar.
Translates to `margin-right: auto` or `margin-left: auto`. When applied inside a flexbox parent, an auto margin consumes all available free space on that side.
Usage of .ms-auto and .me-auto for dynamic spacing in flex containers.
It's like 'Social Distancing' for buttons. One button says 'Leave as much space as possible to my left', pushing itself all the way to the other corner.
Leverage ms-auto or me-auto for elastic spacing in flexbox.

This is the most efficient way to separate a 'Brand' logo on the left from 'User Menu' on the right in a header. You don't need to specify absolute pixels; it simply takes whatever empty space is left and puts it in between.
Add 'ms-auto' to a button if you want it to jump to the right side of its row.
Vertical auto margins (`.mt-auto` and `.mb-auto`) also work in flex columns, which is great for pushing a footer button to the very bottom of a card regardless of the text length.
The application of auto values to margin properties within a flexible box layout to distribute empty space.
Opacity utilities make elements see-through (0, 25, 50, 75, 100), and shadows add a dark glow beneath elements to give them 'depth'.

Bootstrap provides `.opacity-*` classes for controlling transparency and `.shadow` classes for adding elevations. These utilities help implement hierarchical UI designs where certain elements 'float' above others.
Classes: `.opacity-50`, `.shadow-sm`, `.shadow-lg`, `.shadow-none`. Shadows use complex `box-shadow` values with multiple layers for a professional look.
Predefined classes for transparency (.opacity) and elevation (.shadow).
Opacity is like a 'Ghost' that can be solid or transparent. Shadow is like a 'Floating Platform' that looks higher up because it's casting a shadow on the floor.
Apply .opacity-* for transparency and .shadow-* for depth and elevation effects.
Bootstrap 5 added specific 'Opacity' utilities that were not available in version 4. These are useful for disabled states or for creating subtle UI overlays without writing custom inline CSS styles.
Use 'shadow' if you want your buttons or boxes to pop off the screen and look like real objects.
You can combine `.shadow` with hover transition utilities and `:hover` classes to make cards 'rise up' when a user hovers over them.
The set of utility classes for controlling the alpha transparency and box-shadow elevation of elements.

questions.question: How do you implement 'Floating Labels' in Bootstrap 5?

answer_variants.answer: Wrap an `<input>` and a `<label>` in a div with the class `.form-floating`.
Floating labels allow you to have labels that sit inside the input and move to the top when the user starts typing. You must place the `<input>` *before* the `<label>` for this to function correctly.

Syntax: `
`.
Uses .form-floating wrapper with specific input-label ordering.
It's like a 'Magic Label'. When you aren't using the box, the label is big and in the middle. The moment you start writing, it jumps up to the ceiling to get out of your way.
Wrap an input and label in .form-floating with a placeholder defined.

The 'placeholder' attribute is mandatory for internal reasons related to CSS's `:placeholder-shown` pseudo-class. Even if you don't want to show a placeholder, it must exist for the floating logic to work.
It's that cool animation where the input name slides up and shrinks when you click into the text box.
This component is great for saving space on mobile, as you don't need a separate line for the label above the input field.
A form layout where labels interactively transition above the input field upon user focus or value entry.
They are simple shortcuts for making vertical (`vstack`) or horizontal (`hstack`) flexbox lines without writing the full `.d-flex` syntax.
Stacks are an abstraction of flexbox. `.vstack` stacks items vertically with a full-width container, while `.hstack` places them in a row. They include support for the `gap` utility (e.g., `.gap-3`).
`.vstack` sets `display: flex`, `flex-direction: column`, and `width: 100%`. `.hstack` sets `display: flex`, `flex-direction: row`, and `align-items: center`.
Shorthand flexbox utilities for vertical and horizontal alignment.
It's like a 'Stack of Pancakes' (vstack) or a 'Row of Soldiers' (hstack). You don't have to specify how they stand; the class name does it for you.
Use .vstack for columns and .hstack for rows with automatic flexbox properties.
Stacks are better than the standard grid for simple layouts because they don't require the overhead of 'Rows' and 'Columns' padding rules. They are ideal for button groups or simple vertical lists.
If you want to put 3 buttons in a vertical line, just wrap them in a div called 'vstack'.
You can use `.ms-auto` within an `hstack` to create 'split' navbars or toolbars with zero custom CSS, taking advantage of flexbox's distribution logic.
High-level flexbox abstractions for creating vertical and horizontal element stacks.

questions.question: How do you customize 'Z-index' layers in Bootstrap?

answer_variants.answer: You go into the Sass variables and change the numbers in the `$zindex-levels` map.

Bootstrap manages z-indexes through a dedicated Sass map. To change them, you should override the map values (e.g., `$zindex-modal: 2000`) before the main Bootstrap build, ensuring your layers don't clash with the defaults.
Z-index layers are defined in `_variables.scss` within the `$zindex-levels` map. It includes defined tiers for dropdowns, tooltips, and modals.
Overriding the $zindex-levels Sass map for custom layer management.
It's like 'Floor Numbers' in an elevator. If you want the VIP lounge to be above the Roof, you have to tell the elevator engineers (Sass) to change the floor numbers.
Reassign z-index variables in Sass to modify the stacking hierarchy.
Bootstrap provides 'low' z-indexes (1-3) for basic interactive elements and 'high' ones (1000+) for overlays. This prevents accidental overlaps between simple page elements and critical UI popups.
If your 'Cookie Banner' is stuck behind your 'Navigation Bar', you can fix it by giving it a higher z-index number.
With the rise of sticky headers and complex sidebars, it's often necessary to increase the modal z-index to 3000+ to ensure it's truly globally on top of everything.
The mechanism of defining and adjusting CSS z-index values via the framework's theme configuration.

questions.question: What is the 'Utility API' introduced in Bootstrap 5?

answer_variants.answer: It's a way for you to add your own custom 'shortcuts' (like 'p-6') into Bootstrap's build system easily.

The Utility API is a Sass-based system that generates CSS utilities based on maps. It allows developers to add, remove, or modify utility classes (like spacing, display, or color) without writing boilerplate CSS.
Accessed via the `$utilities` map in `_utilities.scss`. It uses a specific schema to define properties, class names, and responsive modifiers.
Sass-driven engine for generating and customizing utility classes.
It's like a 'Stamp Factory'. You give the machine a 'Logo' (property) and 'Ink' (values), and it automatically stamps out thousands of tiny stickers (classes) for you to use.
A power-user tool for generating custom utility classes via Sass maps.

This is how Bootstrap 5 avoids becoming as large as Tailwind while still offering 'Tailwind-like' flexibility. You can disable all utilities you don't use to keep your CSS file extremely small (e.g., removing all border-color utilities you aren't using).
It's the 'Master Switchboard' for almost every shortcut class in Bootstrap.
You can use the `state: hover` option in the API to automatically generate hover-specific utility classes (like `.hover-bg-dark`) that don't exist in the default build.
The Sass-based data structure and generation logic used to create the framework's functional CSS classes.
